Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2009 02:05PM tooyoungtohavebc wrote: Hi Frankie, I had a lumpectomy and node dissection/removal a few years ago and had a lot of the same symptoms you have. I lost use of my hand for a while. I could not grip objects, could not raise my arm over my head and had a lot of numbness both on under side of arm and in fingertips. I was doing everything I could to try to recover and after about 4 weeks, I had my onc provide me a recommendation to see a physical therapist. It made all the difference. I just had one session with her and she gave me tips that worked. Best thing she did was tell me to put a few tennis balls in a sock and stand against a wall and work the balls up and down my back. Sounds crazy but almost immediately I saw improvement. Now that being said, I still have tingling all up my arm and some numbness too, but my grip came back and my arm is pretty normal otherwise. So you might want to see a physical therapist about the arm. Good luck in your recovery

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2010 09:22AM tooyoungtohavebc wrote: Hi raro, I saw your post about pain meds so wanted to reply here. I also have mets to my bones in my back. Last year when I was on the super herceptin and zometa, I started having a lot of back pain and also had pain that ran from my lower spine down my leg...i self diagnosed as sciatica. At first I suspected it was the bone mets getting worse (as did my onc), but guess what...once I went off the chemo, the pain went away. So I told my doc that I think the drugs cause so much swelling that everything is pushing on each other in my back and causing pain and he agreed. So your pain might not be from the mets but from swelling due to the chemo etc. I took aleve for my pain and also got some hydrocodone which helped when things were real bad. Hope you are doing better:) nothing worse than frigging back pain!

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2011 11:43PM tooyoungtohavebc wrote: Heya Chemosabi, I know exactly how you feel. I am at the 6 year mark of this crap and a few months ago I was about to tell my doc...I AM DONE! The current chemo that i am on is Gemzar and it's been my roughest one. I had so much pain and discomfort from this stuff. I think my doc knew I had reached my boiling point and he suggested changing the frequency of the dosage so that i only have to go once a month and it made a HUGE diff. Now the cancer is all still there...just slowed down a bit...but at least I have some good days. He also has given me time off in between chemos just so I get to feel semi normal and prep mentally for the next one when it comes. I am completely a person who believes in QOL vs just breathing. I don't have kids but I have a great hubby that I would hate to leave and I also lost my mom to cancer (she passed at 47) so I have always said I want to try to outlive her...cuz I know she would want me to. But that being said...I have prepared my family and my hubs that at some point I might say enough is enough and stop treatment because of how hard it is. Just wanted you to know that you aren't alone in feeling the way you do. My only thoughts would be to maybe give Navelbine a shot and see how you feel. I know it gets old, but maybe it will be the one to make a difference and/or be more tolerable for you.  Hugs buddy!

I tried mouthwashes (and still do sometimes) but I spent a bunch of time online doing research and found one suggestion that just does the trick every time. It will sound crazy but take a small teaspoon of sugar..yep good old sugar, and pour it on your tongue and get it to the other areas that hurt. then just rinse with water. You may be in for a nice surprise. for me it works immediately. I also shared it with my neighbor who had mouth issues and she continually thanks me for the suggestion because she regularly benefits from it. After getting the MJ card from a diff doc, I told my onc what I was doing and he was totally onboard (just as I knew he would be) he actually wrote me a permission slip to get it too even though I already had it from the other doc. So I am all for whatever helps at this point. I haven't had to use it much since my Gemzar dosage was lowered, but it is there if I need it.

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2009 06:54PM tooyoungtohavebc wrote: Hi Lila, I gotta tell ya, after doing a few months of Ixempra I felt the same as you. I had no quality of life. And to top it all off, just a few weeks after I was done, the tumors started growing again. I told my doc, not to ever ask me to do that chemo again or any other for a while. I completely agree with you that QOL matters too. I am still have side effects from Ixempra. I still have a lot of problems with my feet and neuropathy. Sucks. I am now doing a herceptin clinical trial where there are side effects but nothing in comparison to Ixempra. How bout asking if your doc can give you a break from the stuff for a while...even a few months will help. Or how about a lower dosage. It has been 7 months since I was done with chemo and I still would have a hard time doing another one yet. Hugs

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2010 02:11PM tooyoungtohavebc wrote: That is creepy Linda! Seems too concidental to not mean anything. I attribute developing my cancer to growing up on air force bases my whole childhood. I was born on one and my dad was a veteran so spent his life in the military. My mom died of cancer when I was 10 (not BC), my dad died of complications of alzheimers and parkinsons at the age of 51. Have had 2 brothers who had serious heart problems (1 had an actual heart attack) at around 35 years old. My other siblings have had other strange health probs. We all joke that we were lucky to get good brains! But all jokes aside, I looked at the incidence of cancer near the base we spent most of our time at and the percentages were high. And during the 70s they did not regulate the bases and toxicity like they do now. We also used to travel abroad twice year on cargo planes which emitted a lot of radiation. Again I think this HAD to have something to do with my getting cancer....maybe I am crazy..but me thinks not.
